yoruba: Kí o tẹ orúkọ ìdánimọ̀ àti ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ sórí ibùdó-ìtàkùn tó jọ ògidì.

english: Phishing attacks can trick you into giving up your passwords or trick you into installing malware on your device.
yoruba: Ìdojúkọ Fíṣíìnì lè tàn ọ́ fi kí o fi ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ sílẹ̀, tàbí tàn ọ́ láti fi iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àidara sórí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ.

english: Attackers can use malware to remotely control your device, steal information, or spy on you.
yoruba: Adojúkọni lè lo iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àrànkàn láti fi pàṣẹ fún ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ, jí ìwífún-un rẹ, tàbí fi ṣe alamí.

english: This guide will help you to identify phishing attacks when you see them and outline some practical ways to help defend against them.
yoruba: Ìtọ́nà yìí yóò ràn ọ́ lọ́wọ́ láti tètè dá ìdojúkọ Fíṣíìnì mọ̀ ní kété tí o bá ṣ'alábàápàdée wọn àti àwọn ọ̀nà tó wúlò tí yóò ràn ọ́ lọ́wọ́ láti gbaradì fún wọn

english: Types of Phishing Attacks
yoruba: Àwon oríìsí ìdojúkọ Fíṣíìnì tó wà

english: Phishing for Passwords (aka Credential Harvesting)
yoruba: Fíṣíìnì fún Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé (tí a mọ̀ sí kíkórèe ìwé-ẹ̀rí)

english: Phishers can trick you into giving them your passwords by sending you a deceptive link.
yoruba: Fíṣíìnì fún Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé lè tàn ọ́ kí o ṣ'èṣì fún wọn ní ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ nípa fífi ìsopọ̀ ṣ'ọwọ́ sí ọ.

english: Web addresses in a message may appear to have one destination, but lead to another.
yoruba: Ojúlé ìtàkùn àgbáyé inú iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ lè darí ẹni sí ibòmíràn.

english: On your computer, you can usually see the destination URL by hovering over the link.
yoruba: Lórí ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣáà rẹ, o máa rí URL tí ò ń lọ, bí o bá fẹ́ tẹ ìsopọ̀.

english: But links can be further disguised with lookalike letters, or by using domain names that are one letter off from legitimate domain names and may direct you to a webpage that appears to go to a service that you use, such as Gmail or Dropbox.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n a lè díbọ́n ìsopọ̀ kí o jọ ara, tàbí lílo orúkọ ibùdó ìtàkùn tí ọmọ-ọ̀rọ̀ kan ti dín àti o lè daríì rẹ lọ sí ojúùwé ìtàkùn àgbáyé tó jọ èyí tí o ti máa ń lò, bíi Gmail tàbí Dropbox.

english: These fake replica login screens often look so legitimate that it’s tempting to type your username and password
yoruba: Àwọn ojú ìwé ìfiwọlé wọ̀nyí sábà máa ń rí bí òótọ́ ti yóò tàn ọ́ láti fi orúkọ-ìdánimọ̀ àti ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ sílẹ̀.

english: If you do, you will send your login credentials to the attackers.
yoruba: Bí o bá ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, o ó fi ohun-ẹ̀rí ìfiwọléè rẹ ránṣẹ́ sí adojúkọni.

english: So before typing any passwords, look at the address bar of your web browser.
yoruba: Torí ìdí èyí, kí o tó tẹ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé, yẹ pátákó àdírẹ́ẹ̀sì orí ibùdó-ìtàkùn asàwáríkiriì rẹ wò.

english: It will show the real domain name of the page.
yoruba: Yóò fi ògidì orúkọ agbègbè-ìkápá ojú ìwé náà hàn gbangba.

english: If it doesn't match the site you think you’re logging into, don't continue!
yoruba: Bí kò bá jọ ibùdó tí o mọ̀ tẹ́lẹ̀, máà tẹ̀síwájú!

english: Remember that seeing a corporate logo on the page doesn't confirm it's real.
yoruba: Ṣèrántí wípé àwòrán ilé-iṣẹ́ tí o rí lójú ìwé àyédèrú kò fi hàn wípé ojúlówó ni.

english: Anybody can copy a logo or design onto their own page to try and trick you.
yoruba: Ẹnikẹ́ni lè gbé ẹ̀da àwòrán-ìdánimọ̀ sí orí ojú ìwé tí wọn láti fi tàn ọ́ jẹ.

english: Some phishers use sites that look like popular Web addresses to fool you: https://wwwpaypal.com/ is different from https://www.paypal.com/.
yoruba: Àwọn onífíṣíìnì mìíì máa ń lo ibùdó tó fojú jọ ojúlé-ìtàkùn àgbáyé láti tàn ọ́: https://wwwpaypal.com/ yàtọ̀ sí, https://www.paypal.com/.

english: Similarly https://www.paypaI.com/ (with a capital letter “i” instead of a lowercase “L”) is different from https://www.paypal.com/.
yoruba: Ẹ̀wẹ̀wẹ̀, https://www.paypaI.com/ (tí ò ní "i" nílá dípò "L" kékeré yàtọ̀ sí https://www.paypal.com/.

english: Many people use URL shorteners to make long URLs easier to read or type, but these can be used to hide malicious destinations.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn máa ń lo ayí-atọ́ka-ibùdó-ìtàkùn di kúkúrú URL kí URL gígùn ba rọrùn fún kíkà tàbí tẹ̀, ṣùgbọ́n a lè fi èyí ṣe ìpamọ́ ibùdó burúkú.

english: If you receive a shortened URL like a t.co link from Twitter, try putting it into https://www.checkshorturl.com/ to see where it's really going.
yoruba: Bí o bá gba URL kúkúrú bíi ìsopọ̀-adáríẹni t.co lórí Twitter, gbìyànjú kí o ṣe àyẹ̀wò ìdánilójú https://www.checkshorturl.com/ láti tú àṣìírí ibi tí ò ń lọ gan-an.

english: Remember, it's easy to forge emails so that they display a false return address.
yoruba: Rántí, ó rọrùn láti ṣe àyédèrú ímeèlì kí ó ba han ojúlé ìdápadà ímeèlì ẹ̀tàn.

english: This means that checking the apparent email address of the sender isn't enough to confirm that an email was really sent by the person it appears to be from.
yoruba: Èyí túmọ̀ sí wípé ìṣàyèwò ojúlé ímeèlì àfiṣẹ́-ìjẹ́-ránṣẹ́ kò tó láti mọ̀ bóyá olóòótọ́ ni ẹni tó rí iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ ránṣẹ́ tàbí ìdà kejì.

english: Most phishing attacks cast a wide net.
yoruba: Àwọ̀n fífẹ̀ ni onífíṣíìnì sábà máa ń lò fi ṣiṣẹ́ láabi wọn.

english: An attacker might send emails to hundreds or thousands of people claiming to have an exciting video, important document, or billing dispute.
yoruba: Adojúkọni lè fi ímeèlì ránṣẹ́ sí ọgọọgọ́rùn-ún tàbí ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún ènìyàn láti tẹ àwòrán fídíò alárinrin, ìwé tó ṣe pàtàkì, tàbí àríyànjiyàn ìsanwó kan.

english: But sometimes phishing attacks are targeted based on something the attacker already knows about an individual.
yoruba: Àmọ́ nígbà mìíràn a máa ń daríi ìdojúkọ fíṣíìnì sí ẹni tí a mọ̀ kiní kan nípa rẹ̀.

english: This is called "spearphishing." Imagine you receive an email from your Uncle Boris that says it contains pictures of his kids.
yoruba: Èyí ni a pè ní "Fíṣíìnì ọkọ̀." Rò ó wípé o gba ímeèlì kan láti ọ̀dọ ẹ̀gbọ́n Boris tí ó ní àwòrán ọmọọ̀ rẹ̀ nínú.

english: Since Boris actually has kids and it looks like it is from his address, you open it.
yoruba: Níwọ̀n ìgbà tí Boris ní ọmọ àti pé ìjẹ́rìí sí ojúlé ímeèlìi rẹ̀ jọ èyí tí o mọ̀ tẹ́lẹ̀, o ṣí i.

english: When you open the email, there is a PDF document attached to it.
yoruba: Nígbà tí o ṣí i, o rí fáìlì àgbàsílẹ̀ kékeré PDF tí a fi mọ́ ọn.

english: When you open the PDF, it may even display pictures of Boris’ kids, but it also quietly installs malware on your device that can be used to spy on you.
yoruba: Bí o bá ṣí PDF náà, o lè fi àwòrán ọmọ Boris hàn, ṣùgbọ́n o ti ṣe kẹ́lẹ́kẹ́lẹ́ gbé iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àìdára sórí ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣáà rẹ tí yóò máa ṣe alamí ohun tí o bá ń ṣe wò.

english: Uncle Boris didn't send that email, but someone who knows you have an Uncle Boris (and that he has children) did.
yoruba: Ẹ̀gbọ́n Boris kọ́ ló fi ímeèlì yẹn ránṣẹ́, ṣùgbọ́n ẹni tí o mọ̀ wípé ó ni ẹ̀gbọ́n kan tó ń jẹ́ Boris (tí ó ní ọmọ wẹ́wẹ́).

english: The PDF document that you clicked on started up your PDF reader, but took advantage of a bug in that software to run its own code.
yoruba: PDF tí o ṣíra tẹ̀, tí aka PDF ń ṣí lọ́wọ́, ni iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àìdára yìí yá lò fi fọ́n odùu rẹ̀ ká sórí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ.

english: In addition to showing you a PDF, it also downloaded malware onto your computer.
yoruba: Láfikún sí PDF tí o rí, o ti ṣe àgbàsílẹ̀ ẹ̀da iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àìdára sórí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣáà rẹ.

english: That malware could retrieve your contacts and record what your device's camera and microphone sees and hears.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àìdára yẹn sì lè jí ẹnimímọ̀ àti ká àwòrán tí ayàwòrán àti  gbohùngbohùn rẹ̀ gbọ́ sílẹ̀.

english: The best way to protect yourself from phishing attacks is to never click on any links or open any attachments.
yoruba: Ọ̀nà tó dára jù fún ìdáààbòbò araà rẹ lọ́wọ́ ìdojúkọ fíṣíìnì ni láti máà tẹ ìsopọ̀ adarí ẹni tàbí ṣí àfimọ́ tí a fi mọ́ ímeèlì.

english: But this advice is unrealistic for most people. Below are some practical ways to defend against phishing.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àmọ̀ràn yìí kò jẹ́ nǹkankan fún ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn. Àwọn ọ̀nà tó yanrantí fún ààbò fíṣíìnì wà nísàlẹ̀.

english: How to Help Defend Against A Phishing Attack
yoruba: Ìrànwọ́ bí o ṣe lè gbógunti Ìdojúkọ Fíṣíìnì

english: Keep your software updated
yoruba: Fi àfikún fún iṣẹ́-àìrídìmúù rẹ

english: Phishing attacks that use malware often rely on software bugs in order to get the malware onto your machine.
yoruba: Ìdojúkọ Fíṣíìnì alo iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àìdára sábà máa ń gbójúlé odù-aṣàṣìṣe iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú láti gbé iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àìdára sóríi ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ.

english: Usually once a bug becomes known, a software manufacturer will release an update to fix it.
yoruba: Lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà bí a bá ṣ'àkíyèsíi odù-aṣàṣìṣe, oníṣọnà iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú yóò gbé àfikún àtúnṣe jáde.

english: This means that older software has more publicly-known bugs that could be used to help install malware.
yoruba: Èyí túmọ̀ sí wípé iṣẹ́-àìrídìmúu ti tẹ́lẹ̀ ní odù-aṣàṣìṣe tó pọ̀ tí a lè lò fi gbé iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àìdára sórí ẹ̀rọ.

english: Keeping your software up to date reduces malware risks.
yoruba: Gbígba àfikún iṣẹ́-àìrídìmúù rẹ lóòrèkóòrè yóò dín ewu iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àìdára kù.

english: Use a password manager with auto-fill.
yoruba: Lo aṣàkóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé aṣiṣẹ́fúnrarẹ̀.

english: Password managers that auto-fill passwords keep track of which sites those passwords belong to.
yoruba: Aṣàkóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé aṣiṣẹ́fúnrarẹ̀ yóò ṣe àpamọ̀ ibùdó tí o ti ń lo ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ọ̀hún.

english: While it’s easy for a human to be tricked by fake login pages, passwordmanagers are not tricked in the same way.
yoruba: Bí ó ṣe rọrùn fún ènìyàn tó láti bọ́ sí pánpẹ́ ojú ìwé ìfiwọlé ayédèrú, aṣàkóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ò le è lùgbàdí irú ẹ̀tàn bẹ́ẹ̀.

english: If you use a password manager (including the built-in password manager in your browser), and it refuses to auto-fill a password, you should hesitate and double check the site you’re on.
yoruba: Bí o bá ń lọ aṣàkóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé (títí kan aṣàkóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tó bá asàwáríkiriì rẹ́ wà), tí ó kọ̀ láti ṣiṣẹ́ kíkọ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé fúnra rẹ̀, ó yẹ kí o ṣe iyèméjì, kí o ṣe àtúnyẹ̀wò ibùdó tí o wà.

english: Better yet, use randomly generated passwords so that you are forced to rely on auto-fill, and less likely to type your password into a fake login page.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, lo ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé alágbára tí aṣàkóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé lè kọ fúnra rẹ̀ lórí ojú ìwé ìfiwọlé ayédèrú dípò kí o fi ọwọ́ọ̀ rẹ tẹ̀ ẹ́.

english: Verify Emails with Senders
yoruba: Jẹ́rìí sí ímeèlì pẹ̀lú afiṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ ránṣẹ́

english: One way to determine if an email is a phishing attack is to check via a different channel with the person who supposedly sent it.
yoruba: Ọ̀nà kan láti mọ̀ bí ímeèlì kan bá jẹ́ ìdojúkọ Fíṣíìnì ni wíwòó ní ìkànnì mìíràn láti yẹ ẹni tó fi ránṣẹ́ wò.

english: If the email was purportedly sent from your bank, don’t click on links in the email.
yoruba: Bí ímeèlì náà bá wá láti ilé-ìfowópamọ́ọ̀ rẹ, máà tẹ ìsopọ̀ adarí ẹni sí ojú ìwé mìíràn tí a fi sí inú ímeèlì náà.

english: Instead, call your bank or open your browser and type in the URL of your bank's website.
yoruba: Kàkà bẹ́ẹ̀, pe ilé-ìfowópamọ́ọ̀ rẹ tàbí kí o ṣí aṣàwáríkiriì rẹ kí o sì tẹ URL ilé-ìfowópamọ́ọ̀ rẹ sí i.

english: Likewise, if your Uncle Boris sends you an email attachment, call him on the phone and ask if he sent you pictures of his kids before opening it.
yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́, bí ẹ̀gbọ́n Boris bá fi ímeèlì tí o ní àfimọ́ nínú, pè é lórí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ kí o béèrè bóyá ó fi àwòrán ọmọ rẹ̀ ránṣẹ́ kí o tó ó ṣí i.

english: Open Suspicious Documents in Google Drive
yoruba: Ṣí ìwé afurasí nínú Google Drive

english: Some people expect to receive attachments from unknown persons.
yoruba: Àwọn ènìyàn ń fojú sọ́nà fún ìfimọ́ láti ọwọ́ ẹni tí o kò mọ̀.

english: For example, journalists commonly receive documents from sources.
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, oníròyìn sábà máa ń gba ìwé láti ibi pàtàkì oríṣiríṣi.

english: But it can be difficult to verify that a Word document, Excel spreadsheet, or PDF file isn't malicious.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ó lè nira láti ṣe ìjẹ́rìísí bóyá ìwé Word, àtẹ́kalẹ̀ Excel, tàbí fáìlì PDF kì í ṣe ti búburú.

english: In these cases, don't double-click the downloaded file.
yoruba: Bí èyí bá wáyé, o kò gbọdọ̀ ṣíra tẹ fáìlì tí o gba ẹ̀dàa rẹ̀ sílẹ̀ lẹ́rìnmejì.

english: Instead, upload it to Google Drive or another online document reader.
yoruba: Kàkà bẹ́ẹ̀, gbé e sóríi Google Drive tàbí akàwé mìíràn lórí ayélujára.

english: This will turn the document into an image or HTML, which almost certainly will prevent it from installing malware on your device.
yoruba: Èyí yóò yí ìwé náà padà sí àwòrán tàbí sí HTML, tí yóò dí gbígbé iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àìdára lọ́wọ́ lórí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ.

english: If you're comfortable with learning new software and willing to spend time setting up a new environment for reading mail or foreign documents, there are dedicated operating systems designed to limit the effect of malware.
yoruba: Bí ó bá hùn ọ́ láti kọ́ ìmọ̀ iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú tuntun fún kíka ímeèlì tàbí kíka ìwé ilẹ̀ òkèèrè, ó ní ẹ̀rọ ìṣiṣẹ́ tí yóò dín ipa iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àìdára kù.

english: TAILS is a Linux-based operating system that deletes itself after you use it.
yoruba: TAILS jẹ́ ti ẹ̀rọ ìṣiṣẹ́ ti Linux tó máa ń pa araà rẹ̀ rẹ́ lẹ́yìn tí a bá lò ó tán.

english: Qubes is another Linux-based system that carefully separates applications so that they cannot interfere with each other, limiting the effect of any malware.
yoruba: Qubes jẹ́ ẹ̀rọ ìṣiṣẹ́ mìíràn lórí Linux tí máa ń ṣe jẹ́jẹ́ ya iṣẹ́ s'ọ́tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ kí wọ́n ba máà di ara wọn lọ́wọ́, tí yóò dín ipa iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àìdára kù.

english: Both are designed to work on laptop or desktop computers.
yoruba: Méjèèjì ló ń ṣiṣẹ́ lóríi ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá àgbélétan àti àgbélétábìlì.

english: You can also submit untrusted links and files to VirusTotal, an online service that checks files and links against several different antivirus engines and reports the results.
yoruba: O kò le è fi ìsopọ̀ àti fáìlì tí o kò fọkàn tàn sí VirusTotal, iṣẹ́ orí ayélujára ayẹ fáìlì àti ìsopọ̀ wò láti lòdì s'ónírúurú agbógunti-odù-àrànká-abẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣájẹ́ tí yóò sì jíhìn àbájáde rẹ̀.

english: This isn't foolproof—antivirus often fails to detect new malware or targeted attacks—but it is better than nothing.
yoruba: Èyí kò dájú - antivirus sábà máa ń kùnà láti rí iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àìdára tuntun tàbí ìdojúkọ - ṣùgbọ́n ó dára ju àìsíi rẹ̀ lọ.

english: Any file or link that you upload to a public website, such as VirusTotal or Google Drive, can be viewed by anyone working for that company, or possibly anyone with access to that website.
yoruba: Fáìlìkífáìlì tàbí ìsopọ̀kísopọ̀ tí o bá gbé sórí ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé gbogboògbò, bíi VirusTotal tàbí Google Drive, lè jẹ́ wíwò fún ẹnikẹ́ni tó bá ń ṣiṣẹ́ fún ilé-iṣẹ́ yẹn, tàbí ẹnikẹ́ni tó bá ní ààyè sí ibùdó-ìtàkùn yẹn.

english: If the information contained in the file is sensitive or privileged communications, you may want to consider an alternative.
yoruba: Bí ìwífún inúu fáìlì náà bá jẹ́ èyí tí ẹnìkejì ò gbọdọ̀ rí, o lè fẹ́ lo òmíràn.

english: Be Careful of Emailed Instructions
yoruba: Ṣọ́ra fún àlàyé inú ímeèlì

english: Some phishing emails claim to be from a computer support department or technology company and ask you to reply with your passwords, or to allow a “computer repair person” remote access to your computer, or to disable some security feature on your device.
yoruba: Àwọn ímeèlì Fíṣíìnì kan máa ń parọ́ wípé àjọ alátìlẹ́yìn fún ilé iṣẹ́ ìmọ̀ ẹ̀rọ ni àwọn ń ṣe, wọ́n á sì ní kí o fi ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ ṣọwọ́, tàbí f'ààyè gba "atẹ́rọ̀ ayárabíàṣá ṣe" láti wọ ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣáà rẹ, tàbí yọ ààbò orí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ kúrò.

english: The email might give a purported explanation of why this is necessary, by claiming, for example, that your email box is full or that your computer has been hacked.
yoruba: rọ́ nípa ìdí tí ó yẹ kí o fi gbọ́ sí wọn lẹ́nu ní ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́ ni ohuninú ímeèlì náà yóò jẹ́, fún àpẹẹrẹ, wípé àpótí ímeèlì rẹ tí kún tàbí wípé olè ti wọ inú ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ

english: Unfortunately, obeying these fraudulent instructions can be bad for your security.
yoruba: Láìbọ́sírere, gbígbọ́ sí àwọn ọ̀daràn wọ̀nyí lẹ́nu lè ṣe àkóbá fún ààbò rẹ.

english: Be especially careful before giving anyone technical data or following technical instructions unless you can be absolutely certain that the request's source is genuine.
yoruba: Ṣọ́ra kí o tó fún ẹnikẹ́ni ní ìwífún tó lè kó ọ síta bí ọmọ ọjọ́ mẹ́ta àyàfi bí ó bá dáa lójú wípé ibi dáadáa ni aṣèbéèrè náà ti wá.

english: If you are at all suspicious of an email or link someone has sent you, don’t open or click on it until you’ve mitigated the situation with the above tips and can be confident it’s not malicious.
yoruba: Bí ìfura bá ṣe ọ́ nípa ímeèlì tàbí ìsopọ̀ tí ẹnìkan fi ránṣẹ́ sí ọ, máà ṣí i tàbí ṣíra tẹ̀ ẹ́ àfi ìgbà tí o bá ti gbìyànjú àwọn ìmọ̀ràn tí a kà sókè wọ̀nyí àti bí o bá rí àrídájú wípé kì í ṣe ti aburú.

english: How to: Enable Two-factor Authentication
yoruba: Bí a ṣe lè: f'ààyègba ìfẹ̀rílàdí Ọlọ́nà-méjì

english: Two-factor authentication (or “2FA”) is a way to let a user identify him or herself to a service provider by requiring a combination of two different authentication methods.
yoruba: Ìfẹ̀rílàdí ọlọ́nà-méjì (tàbí 2FA) ni ìgbẹ́sẹ̀ ìdánimọ̀ òǹlò nípa lílo àkójọpọ̀ ìfẹ̀rílàdí oríṣi méjì láti lo iṣẹ́ apèsè.

english: These may be something that the user knows (like a password or PIN), something that the user possesses (like a hardware token or mobile phone), or something that is attached to or inseparable from the user (like their fingerprints).
yoruba: Èyí lè jẹ́ ohun tí òǹlò mọ̀ (bíi ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tàbí PIN), ohun tí òǹlò ní (bíi àmì iṣẹ́-àrídìmú tàbí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ), tàbí nǹkan tí a fimọ́ tàbí tí kò ṣe é yà s'ọ́tọ̀ lára òǹlò (bíi ìtẹ̀ka wọn).

english: You probably already use 2FA in other parts of your life.
yoruba: O ó ti máa lo 2FA nínú ìgbé ayéè rẹ.

english: When you use an ATM to withdraw cash, you must have both your physical bankcard (something you possess) and your PIN (something that you know).
yoruba: Bí o bá lo ATM láti gbowójádé, o gbọdọ̀ ní ike pélébé ilé-ìfowópamọ́ọ̀ rẹ (ohun tí o ní) àti PIN rẹ (ohun tí o mọ̀)

english: Right now, however, many online services only use one factor to identify their users by default—a password.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, ọ̀pọ̀ iṣẹ́ orí ayélujára á máa lo ìdánimọ̀ kan ṣoṣo fún òǹlò wọn gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ààtòàbáwá - ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé.

english: How does 2FA work online?
yoruba: Báwo ni 2FA ṣe ń ṣiṣẹ́ lórí ayélujára?

english: Several online services—including Facebook, Google, and Twitter—offer 2FA as an alternative to password-only authentication.
yoruba: Àìmọye iṣẹ́ orí ayélujára - títí kan Facebook, Google, àti Twitter - ń pèsèe 2FA gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀nà mìíràn fún ìfẹ̀rílàdí ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé nìkan.

english: If you enable this feature you’ll be prompted for both a password and a secondary method of authentication.
yoruba: Bí o bá f'ààyègba iṣẹ́ yìí, wà á fi ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé àti ọ̀nà mìíràn ṣe ìfẹ̀rílàdí.

english: authentication. This second method is typically either a one-time code sent by SMS or a one-time code generated by a dedicated mobile app that stores a secret (such as Google Authenticator, Duo Mobile, the Facebook app, or Clef).
yoruba: Ọ̀nà kejì ni ọ̀kan nínúu SMS tàbí odù àlòlẹ́ẹ̀kan tí áàpù ẹ̀rọ alágbèéká afohunìkọ̀kọ̀ pamọ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Afẹ̀rílàdí Google, Duo Mobile, áàpù Facebook, tàbí Clef) tí a yà s'ọ́tọ̀ fún iṣẹ́ yìí yóò gbà jáde.

english: In either case, the second factor is your mobile phone, something you (normally) possess.
yoruba: Èyíkéyìí, ọ̀nà kejì ni ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ alágbèékáà rẹ, ohun tí ó sábà máa ń ní.

english: Some websites (including Google) also support single-use backup codes, which can be downloaded, printed on paper, and stored in a safe location as an additional backup.
yoruba: Ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé (títí kan Google) náà nítìlẹ́yìn ìpamọ́ odù alálòlẹ́ẹ̀kan, tí ẹ̀da rẹ̀ ṣe é gbà sórí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ, ṣe é tẹ̀ sórí ìwé, àti fi pamọ́ sí ibìkan.

english: Once you’ve opted-in to using 2FA, you’ll need to enter your password and a one-time code from your phone to access your account.
yoruba: Ní kété tí o bá ti f'ọwọ́ sí i láti máa lo 2FA, o nílò ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ àti odù alálòlẹ́ẹ̀kan láti orí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ alágbèékáà rẹ kí o tó ó r'áàyè wọ ìṣàmúlòo rẹ.

english: Why should I enable 2FA?
yoruba: Kí ló dé tí mo fi gbọdọ̀ f'ààyègba 2FA?

english: 2FA offers you greater account security by requiring you to authenticate your identity with more than one method.
yoruba: 2FA ń fún ìṣàmúlòo rẹ ní ààbò tó péye nípa mímú ọ fi ẹ̀rí làdí ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ ju ọ̀nà kan lọ.

english: This means that, even if someone were to get hold of your primary password, they could not access your account unless they also had your mobile phone or another secondary means of authentication.
yoruba: Èyí túmọ̀ sí wípé, bí ẹnikẹ́ni bá ti ẹ̀ gba ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ mú nípò kìnínní, wọn kò ní le è r'ọ́nà wọ ìṣàmúlòo rẹ àyàfi bí wọ́n bá ní ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ alágbèékáà rẹ tàbí r'ọ́nà ipò-kejì lo ìfẹ̀rílàdí mìíràn.

english: Are there downsides to using 2FA?
yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ 2FA ní àléébù?

english: Although 2FA offers a more secure means of authentication, there is an increased risk of getting locked out of your account if, for example, you misplace or lose your phone, change your SIM card, or travel to a country without turning on roaming.
yoruba: Bótilẹ̀jẹ́pé 2FA ń fún ni ní ààbò tó péye fún ìfẹ̀rílàdí, ewu àtìmóde ìṣàmúlòo rẹ le è wáyé, fún àpẹẹrẹ, o kò mọ ibi tí o ṣ'ọwọ́ọ̀ ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ rẹ sí tàbí o ti pàdánùu rẹ, tàbí pààrọ̀ ike pélébé SIM rẹ, tàbí rìnrìn àjò sí ìlú mìíràn láì tan ìrìn-káàkiri orí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ.

english: Many 2FA services provide a short list of single-use “backup” or “recovery” codes.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ nínú iṣẹ́ 2FA ní ń pèsè àkàsílẹ̀ "àpamọ́" kúkúrú alálòlẹ́ẹ̀kan tàbí odù "ìgbàpadà".

english: Each code works exactly once to log in to your account, and is no longer usable thereafter.
yoruba: Ẹ̀rìnkan o lè lo ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan odù yìí fi wọ ìṣàmúlòo rẹ, kò sì wúlò mọ́ lẹ́yìnwá.

english: If you are worried about losing access to your phone or other authentication device, print out and carry these codes with you.
yoruba: Bí ọ̀kan-àn rẹ kò bá balẹ̀ nípa ìpàdánù ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ rẹ tàbí ẹ̀rọ ìfẹ̀rílàdí mìíràn, tẹ odù wọ̀nyí jáde kí o sì máa gbé e kiri.

english: They'll still work as “something you have,” as long as you only make one copy, and keep it close.
yoruba: Wọn yóò ṣì ṣiṣẹ́ bí "ohun tí o ní," níwọ̀n ìgbà tí o bá tẹ ẹ̀dà kan ṣoṣo.

english: Remember to keep the codes secure and ensure that no one else sees them or has access to them at any time.
yoruba: Kí o sì tọ́júu odù náà kí o rí i dájú wípé ẹlòmíràn kò rí i tàbí r'áàyè sí i nígbàkúùgbà.

english: If you use or lose your backup codes, you can generate a new list next time you’re able to log in to your account.
yoruba: Bí o bá lo odù àkópamọ́ tàbí pàdánùu rẹ, o lè gba òmíràn jáde tí o bá r'áàyè wọ inú ìṣàmúlò rẹ.

english: Another problem with 2FA systems that use SMS messages is that SMS messaging isn't that secure.
yoruba: Ìṣòro mìíràn tí ẹ̀rọ 2FA tó ń lo iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ SMS ni wípé iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ SMS kò l'áàbò tó.

english: It's possible for a sophisticated attacker who has access to the phone network (such as an intelligence agency or an organized crime operation) to intercept and use the codes that are sent by SMS.
yoruba: Ó ṣe é ṣe fún ògbólógbòó adojúkọni láti r'áàyè wọ inúu ìṣàsopọ̀ ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ rẹ (gẹ́gẹ́ bíi àjọ aṣèwádìí ọ̀daràn tàbí ẹgbẹ́ arúfin kan) láti jí àti lo odù tí a lo SMS fi ránṣẹ́ sí ọ.

english: There have also been cases where a less sophisticated attacker (such as an individual) has managed to forward calls or text messages intended for one number to his or her own, or accessed telephone company services that show text messages sent to a phone number without needing to have the phone.
yoruba: Pàápàá adojúkọni tí kì í ṣe ògbólógbòó ti dáríi iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ ẹlòmíràn sórí ilàa tirẹ̀, tàbí r'ọ́nà wọ ilé-iṣẹ́ apèsè àfihàn iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ tí a fi ránṣẹ́ sórí ilà hàn láì nílò ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀.

english: If you're worried about this level of attack, turn off SMS authentication, and only use authenticator apps like Google Authenticator or Authy.
yoruba: Bí ọkàn-an rẹ̀ ò bá balẹ̀ nípa ìdojúkọ, pa ìfẹ̀rílàdí SMS, kí o sì lo áàpù afẹ̀rílàdí bíi Google Authenticator tàbí Authy.

english: Unfortunately this option is not available with every 2FA-enabled service.
yoruba: Láìbọ́sírere, àṣàyàn yìí kò sí lárọ̀ọ́wọ́tó fún gbogbo iṣẹ́ afààyègbà 2FA.

english: In addition, using 2FA means you may be handing over more information to a service than you are comfortable with.
yoruba: Níròpọ̀, lílo 2FA túmọ̀ sí wípé o lè máa gbé ìwífún tó pọ̀ ṣọwọ́ iṣẹ́ tí ò rọ̀ ọ́ lọ́rùn.

english: Suppose you use Twitter, and you signed up using a pseudonym.
yoruba: Bí o bá ń lo Twitter, tí o sì lo orúkọ ìnagijẹ nígbà tí o forúkọsílẹ̀.

english: Even if you carefully avoid giving Twitter your identifying information, and even if you access the service only over Tor or a VPN, if you enable SMS 2FA, Twitter will necessarily have a record of your mobile number.
yoruba: Pàápàá bí o kò bá fi ìdánimọ̀ lẹ́kùnún rẹ́rẹ́ fún Twitter, àti bí o bá wọ̀ ọ́ lóríi Tor tàbí VPN, bí o bá f'ààyègba 2FA SMS, Twitter kò ní ṣaláì ní àkọsílẹ̀ ilà ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ alágbèékáà rẹ.

english: That means that, if compelled by a court, Twitter can link your account to you via your phone number.
yoruba: Èyí ni pé, bí ilé ẹjọ́ bá pa á láṣẹ, Twitter lè fi ilà ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ rẹ dá ọ mọ̀.

english: This may not be a problem for you, especially if you already use your legal name on a given service, but if maintaining your anonymity is important, think twice about using SMS 2FA.
yoruba: Èyí lè máà jẹ́ ìṣòro fún ọ, ìyẹn bí o bá lo orúkọ àbísọọ̀ rẹ lórí iṣẹ́kíṣẹ́, àmọ́ bí pípa ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ mọ́ bá pọn dandan, ṣe àtúnrò nípa lílo 2FA SMS.

english: Finally, research has shown that some users will choose weaker passwords after enabling 2FA, feeling that the second factor is keeping them secure.
yoruba: Níparí, ìwádìí ti fi hàn wípé àwọn òǹlò kan máa ń yan ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tí kò nípọn tó bí wọ́n bá f'ààyègba 2FA tán, pẹ̀lú èrò wípé ọ̀nà kejì yóò dáàbò bò wọ́n.

english: Make sure to still choose a strong password even after enabling 2FA.
yoruba: Rí i dájú wípé o yan ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tí ó lágbára lẹ́yìn tí o bá ti f'ààyègba 2FA.

english: See our creating strong passwords guide for tips.
yoruba: Wo ìtọ́nà bí a ṣe ń ṣẹ̀dá ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlée wa fún olobó.

english: How do I enable 2FA?
yoruba: Báwo ni mo ṣe lè f'ààyègba 2FA?

english: This differs from platform to platform, as does the terminology used.
yoruba: Èyí yàtọ̀ láti agbègbè s'ágbègbè, bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni ìpèlórúkọ wọ́n yàtọ̀.

english: An extensive list of sites supporting 2FA is available at https://twofactorauth.org/.
yoruba: Ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́ àkàsílẹ̀ àwọn ibùdó tó l'átìlẹ́yìn fún 2FA wà ní https://twofactorauth.org/.

english: For the most common services, you can refer to our 12 Days of 2FA post, which shows how to enable 2FA on Amazon, Bank of America, Dropbox, Facebook, Gmail and Google, LinkedIn, Outlook.com and Microsoft, PayPal, Slack, Twitter, and Yahoo Mail.
yoruba: Fún àwọn iṣẹ́ tó wọ́pọ̀, o lè wo Ìtẹ̀jáde 2FA Ọlọ́jọ́ Méjìláa wa, tó ṣàpèjúwe bí o ṣe lè f'ààyègba 2FA lóríi Amazon, Ilé-Ìfowópamọ́ America, Dropbox, Facebook, Gmail ati Google, LinkedIn, Outlook.com àti Microsoft, PayPal, Slack, Twitter, àti Yahoo Mail.

english: If you want better protection against stolen passwords, read through this list and turn on 2FA for all of the important web accounts you rely on.
yoruba: Bí o bá fẹ́ ààbò tó kójú òṣùwọ̀n tí kò ní í jẹ́ kí olè lè jí ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ, ka àkàsílẹ̀ yìí kí o sì tan 2FA sílẹ̀ fún gbogbo ìṣàmúlò ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tí o ṣe kókó tí o gbẹ́kẹ̀lé.

english: Creating Strong Passwords Using Password Managers
yoruba: Lílo Alákòóso Ọ̀rọ̀-Ìfiwọlé fún Ìṣẹ̀dá Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tó Lágbára

english: Reusing passwords is an exceptionally bad security practice. If a bad actor gets ahold of a password that you've reused across multiple services, they can gain access to many of your accounts.
yoruba: Àtúnùntúnlò ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé jẹ́ ọ̀nà ààbò tí kò dára. Bí òṣèré ibí bá gbá ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tí o ti tún lò lórí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ iṣẹ́ mú, wọ́n lè r'ọ́nà wọ inú ìṣàmúlò rẹ.

english: This is why having multiple, strong, unique passwords is so important.
yoruba: Torí ìdí èyí ni ó fi dára tí ó sì pọn dandan kí a ní ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tó lágbára, tó sì yàrà ọ̀tọ̀.

english: Fortunately, a password manager can help.
yoruba: Ní rere, alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé lè ṣerànwọ́.

english: A password manager is a tool that creates and stores passwords for you, so you can use many different passwords on different sites and services without having to memorize them.
yoruba: Alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ni irinṣẹ́ tí í máa ń ṣẹ̀dá àti fi ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé pamọ́ fún ọ, kí o ba lè lo onírúurú ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé lóríi onírúurú ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé láì sí wípé ó há a s'ágbárí.

english: Password managers:
yoruba: Alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé:

english: generate strong passwords that a human being would be unlikely to guess.
yoruba: Máa ń ṣàgbajáde ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tó ṣòro fún ọmọ-ènìyàn láti mọ̀.

english: store several passwords (and responses to security questions) safely.
yoruba: Máa ń fi ọ̀gọ̀rọ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé sí ìpamọ́ (àti èsì fún ìbéèrè ààbò) pẹ̀lú ààbò tó péye.

english: protect all of your passwords with a single master password(or passphrase).
yoruba: dáàbò bo ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ pẹ̀lú ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé olúwa (tàbí gbólóhùn ìfiwọlé ọlọ́rọ̀ kan).

english: KeePassXC is an example of a password manager that is open-source and free.
yoruba: KeePassXC ni irúfẹ́ alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tó jẹ́ irinṣẹ́ ìṣísílẹ̀ ọ̀fẹ́.

english: You can keep this tool on your desktop or integrate it into your web browser.
yoruba: O lè tọ́júu irinṣẹ́ yìí sórí ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá àgbélétábìlì rẹ tàbí kí o fi s'ínúu aṣàwákiri ibùdó-ìtàkùn rẹ.

english: KeePassXC does not automatically save changes you make when using it, so if it crashes after you've added some passwords, you can lose them forever.
yoruba: KeePassXC kì í fi àyípadà tí o bá ṣe nígbà tí o bá lò ó pamọ́ fúnra rẹ̀, bí ó bá d'aṣẹ́ sílẹ̀ lẹ́yìn tí o ti fi ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé kún tilẹ̀, o lè pàdánùu rẹ títí láéláé.

english: You can change this in the settings.
yoruba: O lè yí èyí padà nínú ààtò.

english: Wondering whether a password manager is the right tool for you?
yoruba: Ò ń gbèrò bóyá alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ni irinṣẹ́ tó tọ́ sí ọ?

english: If a powerful adversary like a government is targeting you, it might not be.
yoruba: Bí ọ̀tá ńlá bíi ìjọba bá ń lépaà rẹ, o lè máà jẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀.

english: using a password manager creates a single point of failure.
yoruba: Lílo alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé máa ń ṣẹ̀dáa ìkúnnà kan ṣoṣo.

english: password managers are an obvious target for adversaries.
yoruba: Alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé jẹ́ ìlépa gbangba fún ọ̀tá.

english: research suggests that many password managers have vulnerabilities.
yoruba: Ìwádìí ṣíni níyè wípé ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ni ìpalára lè bá.

english: If you’re worried about expensive digital attacks, consider something more low-tech.
yoruba: Bí ọkàn-an rẹ kò bá balẹ̀ lórí ìdojúkọ orí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá olówó iyebíye, o lè lo èyí tí kò gba wàhálà púpọ̀.

english: You can create strong passwords manually (see “Creating strong passwords using dice” below), write them down, and keep them somewhere safe on your person.
yoruba: O lè ṣẹ̀dá ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé àfọwọ́ṣe (wo "bí a ṣe ń lo dice fún ìṣẹ̀dá ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé alágbára" nísàlẹ̀) kọ ọ́ sílẹ̀, kí o tọ́júu rẹ̀ síbi tó l'áàbò.

english: Wait, aren’t we supposed to keep passwords in our heads and never write them down?
yoruba: Dúró, ṣe àgbárí kọ́ ni ó yẹ kí a há ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé sí àti kí a máa kọ ọ́ sílẹ̀ rárá?

english: Actually, writing them down, and keeping them somewhere like your wallet, is useful so you’ll at least know if your written passwords go missing or get stolen.
yoruba: Lóòótọ́, kò burú bí a bá kọ ọ́ sílẹ̀, kí a sì fi pamọ́ síbìkan bí àsùnwọ̀n ìkówósí àfisápò rẹ, èyí yóò ta ọ́ jí b'ọ́rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tí o kọ sílẹ̀ bá di àwátì tàbí bí wọ́n bá jí i.

english: Creating Strong Passwords Using Dice
yoruba: Bí a ṣe ń lo dice fi ṣẹ̀dá ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé alágbára

english: There are a few passwords that you should memorize and that need to be particularly strong.
yoruba: Ó ní àwọn ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé alágbára tí ó yẹ kí o há s'ágbárí.

english: These include:
yoruba: Àwọn ni:

english: passwords for your device
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé fún ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ

english: passwords for encryption (like full-disk encryption)
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé fún ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò (bíi ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò díìskì kíkún)

english: the master password, or “passphrase,” for your password manager
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé olúwa, tàbí gbólóhùn ìfiwọlé ọlọ́rọ̀ kan, fún alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ

english: your email password
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ímeèlì rẹ.

english: One of many difficulties when people choose passwords themselves is that people aren't very good at making random, unpredictable choices.
yoruba: Ìṣòro kan tí àwọn èèyàn bá ń yan ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé fúnra wọn ni pé àwọn èèyàn kò mọ̀ bí a ṣe ń ṣe àṣàyàn láìròtẹ́lẹ̀ àti aláìsọtẹ́lẹ̀.

english: An effective way of creating a strong and memorable password is to use dice and a word list to randomly choose words.
yoruba: Ọ̀nà ìṣẹ̀dá ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tó lágbára tí ó sì ṣe é rántí jù ni bí a bá lo dice àti àkàsílẹ̀ ọ̀rọ̀ láti yan ọ̀rọ̀ láìròtẹ́lẹ̀.

english: Together, these words form your "passphrase."
yoruba: Lápapọ̀, àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ wọ̀nyí ni "gbólóhùn ìfiwọlé ọlọ́rọ̀ kan."

english: A "passphrase" is a type of password that is longer for added security.
yoruba: Gbólóhùn ìfiwọlé ọlọ́rọ̀ kan ni irúfẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé aláàbò tó máa ń gùn.

english: For disk encryption and your password manager, we recommend selecting a minimum of six words.
yoruba: Fún ìyí-dátà-padà-sí-odù-ààbò díìskì àti alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ, ó kéré jù, yan ọ̀rọ̀ mẹ́fà.

english: Why use a minimum of six words?
yoruba: Kí ni ṣe tí ó fi yẹ kí o lo ọ̀rọ̀ mẹ́fà?

english: Why use dice to pick words in a phrase randomly?
yoruba: Kí ní dé tí ó fi yẹ kí o fi dice ṣe ìṣàjọ ọ̀rọ̀ onígbólóhùn kan láìròtẹ́lẹ̀?

english: The longer and more random the password, the harder it is for both computers and humans to guess.
yoruba: Bí ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé bá ṣe gùn àti bí ó ṣe jẹ́ àṣàyàn láìròtẹ́lẹ̀, bẹ́ẹ̀ni yóò ṣe le fún ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣáà àti ènìyàn láti rò.

english: here’s a video explainer.
yoruba: fídíò alálàyé kan rè é.

english: Try making a passphrase using one of EFF's word lists.
yoruba: Gbìyànjú kí o lo àṣàkalẹ̀ ọ̀rọ̀ EFF láti ṣe gbólóhùn ìfiwọlé ọlọ́rọ̀ kan.

english: If your computer or device gets compromised and spyware is installed, the spyware can watch you type your master password and could steal the contents of the password manager.
yoruba: Bí adojúkọ bá dojúkọ ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣáà rẹ tàbí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ, tí iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú alamí wà lóríi rẹ̀, iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú alamí lè máa wò ọ́ bí o bá ń tẹ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé olúwaà rẹ.

english: So it's still very important to keep your computer and other devices clean of malware when using a password manager.
yoruba: Torí náà ó pọn dandan kí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣáà rẹ àti ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ ó wà ní mímọ, kí o máà sí iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àìdára bí o bá ń lo alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé.

english: A Word About “Security Questions”
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ nípa "ìbéèrè ààbò"

english: Beware of the “security questions” that websites use to confirm your identity.
yoruba: Kíyèsára fún "ìbéèrè ààbò" tí ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé ń lò fi ṣe ìfẹsẹ̀múlẹ̀ ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ.

english: Honest answers to these questions are often publicly discoverable facts that a determined adversary can easily find and use to bypass your password entirely.
yoruba: Ìdáhùn òdodo sí ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí máa ń wà ní àrọ́wọ́tóo gbogboògbò tí yóò sì gbé ẹ̀rí tí ọ̀tá lè lò fi fo ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ kọjá yányán.

english: Instead, give fictional answers that no one knows but you.
yoruba: Kàkà bẹ́ẹ̀, fi ìdáhùn tí kì í ṣe òdodo pọ́nbélé tí ẹnìkan yàtọ̀ sí ìwọ kò mọ̀ sílẹ̀.

english: For example, if the security question asks:
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, bí ìbéèrè ààbò bá ní:

english: “What was the name of your first pet?”
yoruba: Kí ni orúkọ ẹranko ilé tí o fẹ́ràn àkọ́kọ́ọ̀ rẹ?

english: Your answer could be a random password generated from your password manager.
yoruba: Ìdáhùn rẹ lè jẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé aláìròtẹ́lẹ̀ tí alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ gbàjáde.

english: You can store these fictional answers in your password manager.
yoruba: O lè fi ìdáhùn àìṣòdodo pọ́nbélé wọ̀nyí s'ínúu alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ.

english: Think of sites where you’ve used security questions and consider changing your responses.
yoruba: Ronú nípa ibùdó-ìtàkùn tí o ti lo ìbéèrè ààbò rí kí o sì gbèrò nípa ìyípadà èsì rẹ.

english: Do not use the same passwords or security question answers for multiple accounts on different websites or services.
yoruba: Máà lo ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tàbí ìbéèrè ààbò kan náà fún gbogbo ìṣàmúlò fún gbogbo ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyéè tàbí iṣẹ́.

english: Syncing Your Passwords Across Multiple Devices
yoruba: Ìmúṣiṣẹ́pọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ lóríi ẹ̀rọ gbogbo

english: Many password managers allow you to access your passwords across devices through a password-synchronizing feature.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ń fi ààyè gba ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ lórí gbogbo ẹ̀rọ - nípa àmúṣiṣẹ́pọ̀.

english: This means when you sync your password file on one device, it will update it on all of your devices.
yoruba: Èyí ni pé bí o bá mu ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ ṣiṣẹ́ pọ̀ lórí ẹ̀rọ kan, yóò ṣàfikún lórí ẹ̀rọ ìyókù

english: Password managers can store your passwords “in the cloud,” meaning encrypted on a remote server.
yoruba: Alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé lè fi ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ pamọ́ "s'ínúu kùkukùru," tí ó túmọ̀ sí wípé a ti yí dátà rẹ̀ padà sí odù ààbò sínú apèsè àrọ́wọ́tó.

english: When you need your passwords, these managers will retrieve and decryptthe passwords for you automatically
yoruba: Bí o bá nílòo ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ, alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé wọ̀nyí yóò ṣe àgbàjáde ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé, yóò sì tú ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tí a ti yí padà sí odù ààbò fúnra rẹ̀.

english: Password managers that use their own servers to store or help synchronize your passwords are more convenient, but are slightly more vulnerable to attacks.
yoruba: Alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tí ń fi apèsèe tirẹ̀ ṣe ìpamọ́ tàbí ìrànwọ́ àmúṣiṣẹ́pọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ rọrùn bíi kàásínǹkan, ṣùgbọ́n ìpalára ìdojúkọ lè bá wọn.

english: If your passwords are stored both on your computer and in the cloud, an attacker does not need to take over your computer to find out your passwords.
yoruba: Bí o bá fi ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ pamọ́ sí orí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá àti s'ínúu kùkukùru, adojúkọni kò ní í lo ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣáà rẹ láti mọ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ.

english: (They will need to break your password manager’s passphrase though.)
yoruba: (Wọ́n ní láti fọ́ gbólóhùn ìfiwọlé ọlọ́rọ̀ kan ti alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ.)

english: If this is concerning, don't sync your passwords to the cloud and instead opt to store them on just your devices.
yoruba: Bí èyí bá kàn ọ́ gbọ̀ngbọ̀n, máà mú ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ ṣiṣẹ́ pọ̀ s'ínúu kùkukùru, kàkà bẹ́ẹ̀ fi wọ́n pamọ́ sórí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ.

english: Keep a backup of your password database just in case.
yoruba: Tọ́júu ìkópamọ̀ ilée dátà ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ torí aìíṣeémọ̀.

english: Having a backup is useful if you lose your password database in a crash, or if your device is taken away from you.
yoruba: Àkópamọ́ wúlò bí o bá pàdánù ilé dátà ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ látàrí ìdaṣẹ́sílẹ̀, tàbí tí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ bá di jíjí.

english: Password managers usually have a way to make a backup file, or you can use your regular backup program.
yoruba: Alákòóso ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé sábà máa ń ní ọ̀nà láti ṣe àkópamọ́ fáìlì, tàbí kí o lo iṣẹ́ àkópamọ́ tó wọ́pọ̀.

english: Multi-Factor Authentication and One-Time Passwords
yoruba: Ìfẹ̀rílàdí Ọlọ́nà púpọ̀ àti ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ẹ̀rìnkan.

english: Strong, unique passwords make it much harder for bad actors to access your accounts to further protect your accounts, enable two-factor authentication
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé alágbára, aláràọ̀tọ̀ kì í mú u rọrùn fún òṣèré ibi láti r'áàyè wọ ìṣàmúlò rẹ fún ìfẹ̀rílàdí ọlọ́nà méjì.

english: Some services offer two-factor authentication (also called 2FA, multi-factor authentication, or two-step verification), which requires users to possess two components (a password and a second factor) to gain access to their account.
yoruba: Àwọn iṣẹ́ kan a máa fún ni ìfẹ̀rílàdí ọlọ́nà méjì (tí a tún ń pè ní 2FA, ìfẹ̀rílàdí ọlọ́nà púpọ̀ tàbí ìfẹ̀rílàdí ìgbésẹ̀ méjì), tí òǹlò gbọdọ̀ lo ohun méjì (ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé àti ọ̀nà mìíràn) láti r'áàyè wọ ìṣàmúlò wọn.

english: The second factor could be a one-off secret code or a number generated by a program running on a mobile device.
yoruba: Ọ̀nà kejì lè jẹ́ odù alálòlẹ́ẹ̀kan tàbí òǹkà tí ẹ̀rọ alágbèéká gbàjáde.

english: Two-factor authentication using a mobile phone can be done in one of two ways:
yoruba: Ọ̀nà méjì ni a lè fi ṣe ìfẹ̀rílàdí ọlọ́nà méjì lórí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ alágbèéká:

english: your phone can run an authenticator application that generates security codes (such as Google Authenticator or Authy) or you can use a stand-alone hardware device (such as a YubiKey); or
yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ rẹ lè ṣiṣẹ́ ìfẹ̀rílàdí láti ṣe àgbájáde odù ààbò (gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Afẹ̀rílàdí Google tàbí Authy) tàbí kí o lo ẹ̀rọ iṣẹ́ àìrídìmú àládàádúró (gẹ́gẹ́ bíi YubiKey); tàbí

english: the service can send you an SMS text message with an extra security code that you need to type in whenever you log in.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́ náà lè fi àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́ SMS pẹ̀lú àfilé odù ààbò tí ó ní láti tẹ̀ nígbàkúùgbà tí o bá fẹ́ wọlé.

english: If you have a choice, pick the authenticator application or stand-alone hardware device instead of receiving codes by text message.
yoruba: Kàkà kí o gba àfilé odù ààbò, o lè yan iṣẹ́ ìfẹ̀rílàdí tàbí ẹ̀rọ iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú àládàádúró.

english: It’s easier for an attacker to redirect these codes to their own phone than it is to bypass the authenticator.
yoruba: Ó rọrùn fún adojúkọni láti ṣ'àtúndarí odù wọ̀nyí sórí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ ti wọn ju ìdákọjá afẹ̀rílàdí lọ.

english: Some services, such as Google, also allow you to generate a list of one-time passwords, also called single-use passwords.
yoruba: Àwọn iṣẹ́ kan, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Google, náà máa ń f'ààyè gbà ọ́ láti ṣ'àgbàjáde àkàsílẹ̀ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ẹ̀rìnkan ṣoṣo, tí a tún ń pè ní ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé alálòlẹ́ẹ̀kan.

english: These are meant to be printed or written down on paper and carried with you.
yoruba: Ó yẹ kí a tẹ̀ ẹ́ sórí ìwé tàbí kọ ọ́ sílẹ̀ kí a máa gbé e kiri.

english: Each of these passwords works only once, so if one is stolen by spyware when you enter it, the thief won't be able to use it for anything in the future.
yoruba: Ẹ̀ẹ̀kan ṣoṣo ni ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé wọ̀nyí ń ṣiṣẹ́, torí náà bí iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú alamí bá jí ọkàn, olè náà kò ní le è lò ó fún ohunkóhun lọ́jọ́ iwájú.

english: If you or your organization run your own communications infrastructure, there's free software available that can be used to enable two-factor authentication for accessing your systems.
yoruba: Bí ìwọ tàbí ilé-iṣẹ́ẹ̀ rẹ bá ní irinṣẹ́ ìtàkùrọ̀sọ tirẹ̀, iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú ọ̀fẹ́ wà lárọ̀ọ́wọ́tó tí ó ṣe é lò láti f'ààyègba ìfẹ̀rílàdí ọlọ́nà méjì láti r'áàyè wọ ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ.

english: Look for software offering implementations of the open standard “Time-Based One-Time Passwords” or RFC 6238.
yoruba: Wá iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú tí ó jẹ́ ti ìṣísílẹ̀ "Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé Ẹ̀̀rìnkan ṣoṣo Adálórí Àkókò" tàbí RFC 6238.

english: Sometimes, You Will Need to Disclose Your Password
yoruba: Nígbà mìíràn, O ní láti sọ Ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ

english: Laws about revealing passwords differ from place to place.
yoruba: Òfin nípa sísọ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé yàtọ̀ láti ibìkan dé òmíràn.

english: In some jurisdictions you may be able to legally challenge a demand for your password while in others, local laws allow the government to demand disclosure — and even imprison you on the suspicion that you may know a password or key
yoruba: Nígbà mìíràn o lè kọ̀ jálẹ̀ kí o máà fún ẹnikẹ́ni ní ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọléè rẹ, níbo mìíràn ẹ̀wẹ̀wẹ̀ òfín ìbílẹ̀ f'ààyè gba ìjọba láti béèrè fún ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé ẹnikẹ́ni - àti pàápàá fi ọ́ sí àtìmọ́lé bí o bá jẹ́ afurasí tí ó mọ ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tàbí kọ́kọ́rọ́ kan.

english: Threats of physical harm can be used to force someone to give up their password.
yoruba: A lè lo ìdẹ́rùbà ìpalára ojúkorojú láti fi gba ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé lọ́wọ́ èèyàn.

english: Or you may find yourself in a situation, such as travelling across a border, where the authorities can delay you or seize your devices if you refuse to give up a password or unlock your device.
yoruba: Tàbí kí o bá araà rẹ nínú ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ kan, bíi rírin ìrìn àjò s'ódìkejì ìlú, níbi tí àwọn aláṣẹ lè ti dá ọ dúró tàbí gba ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ bí o bá kọ̀ láti fún wọn ní ọ̀rọ̀-ìfiwọlé tàbí ṣí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ.

english: How to: Circumvent Online Censorship
yoruba: Bí a ṣe ń: fo ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ Ayélujára dá

english: This is a short overview to circumventing online censorship, but is by no means comprehensive.
yoruba: Èyí ni àkótán kúkúrú nípa ìfòdá ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ orí ayélujára, ṣùgbọ́n kì í ṣe ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́.

english: Governments, companies, schools, and Internet providers sometimes use software to prevent their users from accessing certain websites and services.
yoruba: Ìjọba, ilé-iṣẹ́, ilé-ìwé, àti apèsèe ẹ̀rọ-àìrídìmú tí yóò dí òǹlò lọ́wọ́ kí wọ́n ba máà rí ààyè wọ àwọn ibùdó-ìtàkùn kan.

english: This is called Internet filtering or blocking, and it is a form of censorship.
yoruba: Èyí ni a pè ní ìsẹ́ ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára tàbí ìdígàgá, tí í ṣe irúfẹ́ ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ kan.

english: Filtering comes in different forms. Censors can block individual web pages, or even entire websites.
yoruba: Atẹríbọlẹ̀ẹ́ lè dígàgá ojú ìwé ìtàkùn-àgbáyé kan ṣoṣo tàbí gbogbo ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé pọ̀.

english: Sometimes, content is blocked based on the keywords it contains.
yoruba: Nígbà mìíì, ohuninú ojú ìwé orí ayélujára ní í máa ń fa ìdígàgá

english: There are different ways of beating Internet censorship.
yoruba: Onírúurú ọ̀nà ni a fi lè fo ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ orí ayélujára dá.

english: Some protect you from surveillance, but many do not.
yoruba: Àwọn kan ń fi ààbò ìṣọ́ni bò ọ́, ṣùgbọ́n ọ̀pọ̀ ò ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

english: When someone who controls your net connection filters or blocks a site, you can almost always use a circumvention tool to get to the information you need.
yoruba: Bí alákòóso ìṣàsopọ̀ ayélujáraà rẹ bá ṣẹ́ tàbí dígàgá ibùdó kan, o lè lo irinṣẹ́ ìfòdá tí yóò mú ọ rí ìwífún tí o nílò.

english: Note: Circumvention tools that promise privacy or security are not always private or secure.
yoruba: Fiyèsíi: irinṣẹ́ ìfòdá aṣèlérí ààbò tàbí ibi-ìkọ̀kọ̀ kì í sábà í ṣe ti ìkọ̀kọ̀ tàbí ní ààbò.

english: And tools that use terms like “anonymizer” do not always keeps your identity completely secret.
yoruba: Irinṣẹ́ tó ń lo gbólóhùn bíi "anonymizer" kì í sábà pa ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ mọ́ fínnífínní.

english: The circumvention tool that is best for you depends on your threat model.
yoruba: Irinṣẹ́ ìfòdá tó dára jù fún ọ dá lóríi àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà rẹ.

english: If you’re not sure what your threat model is, start here.
yoruba: Bí àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà rẹ ò bá dá ọ lójú ṣáká tó, bẹ̀rẹ̀ níhìn-ín.

english: In this article, we'll talk about four ways to circumvent censorship:
yoruba: Nínú àpilẹ̀kọ yìí, a máa sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ọ̀nà mẹ́rin tí a lè gbà fo ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ orí ayélujára dá.

english: Visiting a web proxy to access a blocked website.
yoruba: Bíbẹ aṣojú ìtàkùn wò láti wọ ibùdó-ìtàkùn tí a ti dígàgáa rẹ̀.

english: Visiting an encrypted web proxy to access a blocked website.
yoruba: Bíbẹ aṣojú ìtàkùn tí a ti yí dátà rẹ̀ padà sí odù ààbò láti wọ ibùdó-ìtàkùn tí a ti dígàgáa rẹ̀.

english: Using a Virtual Private Network (VPN) to access blocked websites or services.
yoruba: Lílo Ìṣàsopọ̀ Àìrí Ìkọ̀kọ̀ (VPN) láti wọ ibùdó-ìtàkùn tàbí iṣẹ́.

english: Using the Tor Browser to access a blocked website or protect your identity.
yoruba: Lílo aṣàwákiri Tor láti wọ ibùdó-ìtàkùn tí a ti dígàgáa rẹ̀ tàbí dáàbò bo ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ.

english: Basic techniques
yoruba: Àwọn ìpìlẹ̀ ìmọ̀

english: Circumvention tools usually work by diverting your web traffic so it avoids the machines that do the blocking or filtering.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́ tí irinṣẹ́ ìfòdá sábà máa ń ṣe ni dídaríi dátà tó ń gba orí ìtàkùn rẹ kí o ba yẹ ẹ̀rọ tó ń ṣe ìdígàgá tàbí ìsẹ́ kúrò.

english: A service that redirects your Internet connection past these blocks is sometimes called a proxy.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́ tí í ṣe àtúndaríi ìṣàsopọ̀ ayélujára fo ìdígàgá kọjá là ń pè ní aṣojú ń'gbà mìíì.

english: HTTPS is the secure version of the HTTP protocol you use to access websites.
yoruba: HTTPS ni ẹ̀dà ààbò fún ìfẹ́nukò HTTP tí ò ń lò fi wọ ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé.

english: Sometimes a censor will only block the insecure (HTTP) version of a site.
yoruba: Nígbà mìíràn Atẹríbọlẹ̀ẹ́ lè dígàgá ẹ̀dà ibùdó àìláàbò (HTTP)

english: That means you can access the blocked site simply by entering the version of the web address that starts with HTTPS.
yoruba: Ìyẹn ni pé o lè wọ ibùdó tí a dígàgá náà bí o bá tẹ ẹ̀dà àdírẹ́ẹ̀sì ibùdóò rẹ tó bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú HTTPS.

english: HTTPS stops censors from reading your web traffic, so they cannot tell what keywords are being sent, or which individual web page you are visiting.
yoruba: HTTPS máa ń dá atẹríbọlẹ̀ dúró láti máà le è ka dátà tó ń gba oríi ìtàkùn rẹ, torí náà wọn kò le è sọ ọ̀rọ̀-aṣínà tí a fi ránṣẹ́, tàbí orí ojú ìwé ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tí ò ń bẹ̀wò.

english: Censors can still see the domain names of all websites you visit.
yoruba: Atẹríbọlẹ̀ ṣì lè rí orúkọ agbègbè ìkápáa gbogbo ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tí o bá lọ.

english: So, for example, if you visit “eff.org/https-everywhere” censors can see that you are on “eff.org” but not that you are on the “https-everywhere” page.
yoruba: ún àpẹẹrẹ, bí o bẹ "eff.org/https-everywhere" wò atẹríbọlẹ̀ lè rí i wípé o wà lóríi "eff.org", ṣùgbọ́n kì í ṣe pé o wà lóríi ojú ìwée "https-everywhere.”

english: If you suspect this type of simple blocking, try entering https:// before the domain in place of http:
yoruba: Tí o bá ní ìfura irúfẹ́ ìdígàgá àìle báyìí, gbìyànjú kí o tẹ https:// síwájú agbègbè ìkápá dípò http:

english: Try installing EFF’s HTTPS Everywhere extension to automatically turn on HTTPS where possible.
yoruba: Gbìyànjú kí o gbé alátànkáa EFF ibi-gbogbo tí yóò fúnra rẹ̀ tan HTTPS níbi tó bá yẹ sórí ẹ̀rọọ̀ rẹ.

english: Another way that you may be able to circumvent basic censorship techniques is by trying an alternate domain name or URL.
yoruba: Ọ̀nà mìíràn tí o lè gbà fi fo ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ dá ni bí o bá lo orúkọ agbègbè-ìkápá mìíràn tàbí URL.

english: For example, instead of visiting http://twitter.com, you might try the mobile version of the site at http://m.twitter.com.
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, kàkà kí o bẹ http://twitter.com wò, o lè gbìdánwò láti ṣí ibùdó náà lóríi ẹ̀dà ti ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ọ alágbèéká ní http://m.twitter.com.

english: Censors that block websites or web pages work from a blacklist of banned websites, so anything that is not on that blacklist will get through.
yoruba: Atẹríbọlẹ̀ tó dígàgá ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tàbí ojú ìwé ìtàkùn-àgbáyé ń fi àkàsílẹ̀ ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé àìdára tí a ti gbẹ́sẹ̀ òfin lé ṣiṣẹ́, torí náà ohunkóhun tí kò bá sí lórí àkàsílẹ̀ àìdára yẹn yóò la ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ kọjá.

english: They might not know of all different versions of a particular website's name—especially if the administrators of the site know it is blocked and register more than one domain.
yoruba: Wọ́n lè máà mọ gbogbo onírúurú ẹ̀dà orúkọ ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé ní pàtó - ju gbogbo rẹ̀ lọ bí alákòóso ibùdó bá mọ̀ wípé a ti dígàgáa rẹ̀ àti pé a orúkọ agbègbè ìkápá tí a fi sílẹ̀ ju ọ̀kan lọ.

english: Web-based proxies
yoruba: Aṣojú orí ìtàkùn-àgbáyé

english: A web-based proxy (such as http://proxy.org/) is a website that lets its users access other blocked or censored websites.
yoruba: Aṣojú orí ìtàkùn-àgbáyé (gẹ́gẹ́ bíi http://proxy.org/) jẹ́ ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tí ń f'ààyè gba òǹlò láti wọ ibùdó tí a dígàgáa rẹ̀ tàbí tẹríi rẹ̀ bọlẹ̀.

english: It is therefore a good way to circumvent censorship.
yoruba: Ọ̀nà tó dára láti fo ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ dá lèyí.

english: In order to use a web-based proxy, visit the proxy and enter the web address that you want to see; the proxy will then display the web page you asked for.
yoruba: Láti lo aṣojú orí ìtàkùn-àgbáyé, bẹ aṣojú náà wò kí o tẹ àdírẹ́ẹ̀sì ibùdó-ìtàkùn tí o fẹ́ rí sí i; aṣojú yìí yóò fi ojúùwé ibùdó-ìtàkùn tí o béèrè fún hàn ọ́.

english: However, web-based proxies don’t provide any security and will be a poor choice if your threat model includes someone monitoring your internet connection.
yoruba: Bótiwùkíórí, aṣojú orí ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé kì í pèsèe ààbò kankan àti pé kò ní ṣ'ẹnuure bí àṣàyàn àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà rẹ bá ní aṣọ́ní tí ń ṣọ́ ìṣàsopọ̀ rẹ.

english: They will not help you to use blocked services such as your instant messaging apps.
yoruba: Wọn kò ní ràn ọ́ lọ́wọ́ láti lo iṣẹ́ tí a ti dígàgá gẹ́gẹ́ bíi áàpù iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ oníwàràǹṣesà rẹ.

english: The web-based proxy will have a complete record of everything you do online, which can be a privacy risk for some users depending on their threat model
yoruba: Aṣojú orí ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé máa ní àkọsílẹ̀ ohun gbogbo tí ò ń ṣe lórí ayélujára, tí ó lè jẹ́ ewu ìdáààbòbò fún òǹlò mìíràn lórí àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà wọn.

english: Encrypted proxies
yoruba: Aṣojú tí dátà rẹ̀ ti yí padà sí odù ààbò

english: Numerous proxy tools utilize encryption to provide an additional layer of security on top of the ability to bypass filtering.
yoruba: Ọ̀kẹ́ àìmọye irinṣẹ́ aṣojú tó ń lo ìyí-dátà-padà-sódù-ààbò láti pèsè ìpele ìròpọ̀ ààbò lórí agbára ìdákọjá ìsẹ́.

english: The connection is encrypted so others cannot see what you are visiting.
yoruba: Ìṣàsopọ̀ náà ti yìí dátà padà sí odù ààbò kí ẹlòmíràn ó máà ba à lè rí ibi tí ò ń bẹ̀wò.

english: While encrypted proxies are generally more secure than plain web-based proxies, the tool provider may have information about you.
yoruba: Nígbà tí aṣojú tí dátà rẹ̀ ti yí padà sí odù ààbò l'áàbò tó péye ju aṣojú orí ìtàkùn-àgbáyé lọ, apèsè irinṣẹ́ náà lè rí ìwífún nípaà rẹ.

english: They might have your name and email address in their records, for instance.
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, wọ́n lè ní orúkọ àti àdírẹ́ẹ̀sì ímeèlì rẹ lákọsílẹ̀.

english: That means that these tools do not provide full anonymity.
yoruba: Ìyẹ́n túmọ̀ sí wípé irinṣẹ́ wọ̀nwọ̀nyí kì í pèsèe àìlórúkọ dójú àlà.

english: The simplest form of an encrypted web proxy is one that starts with “https”— this will use the encryption usually provided by secure websites.
yoruba: Aṣojú ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tí dátà rẹ̀ ti yí padà sí odù ààbò tó rọrùn jù ni “https” - èyí yóò lo ìyí-dátà-padà-sódù-ààbò tí ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tó l'áàbò pèsè.

english: However, be cautious—the owners of these proxies can see the data you send to and from other secure websites.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, ṣọ́ra - àwọn to ni aṣojú wọ̀nyí lè rí dátà tí o fi ránṣẹ́ sí àti bọ̀ wá láti ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé ààbò mìíràn.

english: Ultrasurf and Psiphon are examples of these tools.
yoruba: UltraSurf àti Psiphon jẹ́ àpẹẹrẹ irinṣẹ́ báwọ̀nyí.

english: Virtual Private Networks
yoruba: Ìṣàsopọ̀ Àìrí Ìkọ̀kọ̀

english: A Virtual Private Network (VPN) encrypts and sends all Internet data from your computer through another computer.
yoruba: Ìṣàsopọ̀ Àìrí Ìkọ̀kọ̀ (VPN) máa ń yí dátà padà sí odù ààbò, yóò sì fi gbogbo dátà ránṣẹ́ láti orí ẹ̀rọ-ayélujáraà rẹ sóríi ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá mìíràn.

english: This computer could belong to a commercial or nonprofit VPN service, your company, or a trusted contact.
yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá yìí lè jẹ́ ti iléeṣẹ́ ìṣòwò kan tàbí ilé-iṣẹ́ àìjèèrè apèsèe VPN, ilé iṣẹ́ẹ̀ rẹ, tàbí ẹni mímọ̀.

english: Once a VPN service is correctly configured, you can use it to access webpages, e-mail, instant messaging, VoIP, and any other Internet service.
yoruba: Ní kété tí iṣẹ́ẹ VPN bá ti wà, o lè lò ó fi wọ ojú ìwé ìtàkùn-àgbáyé, ímeelì, iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ oníwàràǹṣesà VoIP, àti iṣẹ́ orí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára tó kù.

english: A VPN protects your traffic from being spied on locally, but your VPN provider can still keep logs of the websites you access, or even let a third party snoop directly on your web browsing.
yoruba: VPN máa ń dáàbò bo ìwífún tó ń kọjá lórí ayélujára kí àwọn alamí má ba à rí i lágbègbè kan, ṣùgbọ́n apèsèe VPN rẹ ṣì lè ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ ibùdó-ìtàkùn-àgbáyé tí o wọ, tàbí jẹ́ kí ẹnìkẹ́ta yọ́ kẹ́lẹ́ wọ inúu aṣàwáríkiri ayélujáraà rẹ.

english: Depending on your threat model, the possibility of a government listening in on your VPN connection or getting hold of VPN logs may be a significant risk.
yoruba: Ó dá lóríi àwòṣe ìdẹ́rùbà rẹ, o ṣe é ṣe kí ìjọba ó máa fẹtíkọ́ ìṣàsopọ̀ VPN rẹ tàbí gbígbá àkọsílẹ̀ VPN rẹ mú lè di ewu ńlá.

english: For some users, this could outweigh the short-term benefits of using a VPN.
yoruba: Fún òǹlò mìíràn, èyí lè lágbára jù f'áǹfààní tó wà nínú lílo VPN fún ìgbà díẹ̀.

english: For information about specific VPN services, click here.
yoruba: Fún àlàyé nípa àwọn iṣẹ́ VPN ní pàtó, ṣíra tẹ ibí.

english: We at EFF cannot vouch for this rating of VPNs.
yoruba: Ní EFF a kò le è jẹ́rìí sí VPN wọ̀nyí.

english: Some VPNs with exemplary privacy policies could be run by devious people.
yoruba: VPN mìíràn tí ó ní ìlànà ààbò tó yàrá ọ̀tọ̀ lè jẹ́ ti ọ̀daràn.

english: Do not use a VPN that you do not trust.
yoruba: O kò gbọdọ̀ lo VPN tí o kò fi ọkàn tàn.

english: Tor is open-source software designed to give you anonymity on the web.
yoruba: Tor jẹ́ iṣẹ́-àìrídìmú orísun-ìṣísílẹ̀ tí a ṣe kí ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ ó ba wà nípamọ́ lórí ìtàkùn àgbáyé.

english: Tor Browser is a web browser built on top of the Tor anonymity network.
yoruba: Aṣàwáríkiri ìtàkùn-àgbáyé ni aṣàwáríkiri Tor tí a kọ́ sóríi ìṣàsopọ̀ àìlórúkọ òǹlò Tor.

english: Because of how Tor routes your web browsing traffic, it also allows you to circumvent censorship.
yoruba: Nítorí bí Tor ṣe ń gbé dátà ká lórí aṣàwáríkiri ibùdó-ìtàkùn rẹ, ó gbà ọ́ láàyè láti fo ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ dá.

english: (See our How to: Use Tor guides for Linux, macOS and Windows).
yoruba: (Wo bí a ṣe ń: lo ìtọ́nà Tor fún Linux, macOS àti Windows)

english: When you first start the Tor Browser, you can choose an option specifying that you are on a network that is censored:
yoruba: Bí o bá ṣí Aṣàwáríkiri Tor, o lè ṣe àṣàyàn àfihàn wípé oríi ìṣàsopọ̀ tí a tẹríi rẹ̀ bọlẹ̀ lo wà:

english: Tor will not only bypass almost all national censorship, but, if properly configured, can also protect your identity from an adversary listening in on your country’s networks. It can, however, be slow and difficult to use.
yoruba: Tor kò ní fo ìtẹríbọlẹ̀ ọ̀pọ̀ ìlú kọjá nìkan, ṣùgbọ́n, bí o bá fàṣẹ fún un bí ó ṣe yẹ, ó lè dáàbò bo ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ kí ó máà bọ́ s'ọ́wọ́ ọ̀tá tó ń tẹ́tí sí ìṣàsopọ̀ ìlúù rẹ. Síbẹ̀, ó lè máa fà tìkọ̀, kò sì rọrùn ní lílò.

english: To learn how to use Tor on a desktop machine, click here for Linux, here for macOS, or herefor Windows, but please be sure to tap “Configure” instead of “Connect” in the window displayed above.
yoruba: Láti ka bí o ṣe lè lo Tor lórí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá àgbélétábìlì, ṣíra tẹ ibí fún Linux, ibí fún MacOS, tàbí ibí fún Windows, àmọ́ jọ̀wọ́ rí i dájú wípé o f'ọwọ́tọ́ "configure" dípò "connect" nínú àwòrán fèrèsé òkè.
